comments.commentBody:
Political pandering!!
What happens with the principle that we are all equal under the law?
Mr. Obama: You lost my vote.
A naturalized citizen that waited in line

I think the point was that by supporting a party that does not have policies for them, the white working class has effectively left itself without a lever in the political process.

Democrats don't feel any pressure to oppose NAFTA or trade deals with Panama or South Korea because it won't win them any votes anyway. And Republicans know they have the white working class votes without having to do anything but talk about guns, God and gays.

It is no accident that the one thing both parties can agree on - free trade - is the one thing that is hurting people without college educations the most.

The notion that unions are a "policy solution" to US economic problems is not workable. Unions worked in the 50s and 60s because the US was the worlds industrial center and the economy was basically closed compared to what it is now. The world has changed and unions are an anachronism. The high labor and benefit costs they demand would simply sink what's left of the US industrial base and do the same for other sectors if unions expanded. The reality is that the world is flat in the words of the Times own Friedman, and returning to the days of trade protectionism or the US manufacturing stuff for our own population are over.

Besides that the general usefulness of unions in the modern US is questionable. Unions had their place when workers were truly abused, but in todays world those kinds of abuses are rare in the US, business treatment of workers is far better regulated, and people have legal recourse that wasn't available in say 1908. Now all unions do is bankrupt companies (GM, Chrysler). And - workers in equivalent non-union environments like auto manufacturing in the south do basically just as well wage wise.

You overlook the big message of the Republican party. That is, if you don't like your life blame gay people, minorities, and those with less than you (i.e., the poor). Sadly, for some seriously angry white voters who think with their hearts and not their heads, they just want someone to hate, so it works.

"The result is that the Democratic Party has failed to develop a coherent or consistent set of policies to address what is now the dominant issue of the day, the violent restructuring of the American economy, which can be seen from many angles: in the continuing after effects of the financial collapse of 2008; in the rise of inequality; in the decline of social and economic mobility; and in the devastating $49,100 drop in average family wealth, from $126,400 in 2007 to $77,300 in 2010, a 39 percent drop of net assets in just three years."
So - what are the Republican's coherent and/or consistenat policies to address that restructuring? If white working class voters turn away from the Democrats because they fail to provide a way forward, then the GOP must be providing one. Except that they're not. Besides, of course, the "It's Obama's fault" talking point.
A question to the author:  (Not necessarily for publication:)  I'd be interested in reading about Michelle Obama's Jewish ancestors, as mentioned at one point in the article.

Have you noticed how the Times always give Sunday and its bigger circulation to Ms. Obama except when they are running negative stories about Ms. Romney? On Friday the Times ran a favorable article about Ms. Romney that they could have put in this space? These editorial decisions are subtle but still important, particularly when you can read all about Obama fund-raising in the Style section.

One of my ancestors was Isaac Winfrey. I know he was a slave owner in the part of the country where Oprah's roots are. None of us can pick those from whom we descend. We can't even pick our own siblings. This story does two things: it highlights the various prisms through which we all view our racist/slave owning past  with some in denial and some facing reality and it highlights the fact that all of us are related. The moral of the story is, "Get over it."
obama back in michigan on sunday  says i need to get used to being home for good!

Is there a Shields/Tribble/Robinson/Obama genealogical family tree that can be reproduced together with this excellent and fascinating article listing the individual names, spouses, dates of birth, dates of death, family lines, etc. from the common ancestor linking down by generation to the present day family members, including Michele Obama and those of her generation (and even down to the next generation level - Sasha and Malia and their counterparts)?

Every one of us is a unique result of our particular lineage, to the extent that if even one person in that lineage had been different, we ourselves would not exist.  Thus, if my own ancestors had not come here more than a century ago from different countries in Europe, they would never have met,  and I would not exist.  African-Americans have the painful awareness that their own African ancestors were brought here as slaves.  Thus the dilemma -- slavery was reprehensible, but people alive today would not possibly have been conceived if history had been other than it was.  Every actually existing person is a sport of nature, in one way or another.  White, Black, or any shade in between, we are all as American as apple pie -- or sweet-potato pie, if we please.  The point to remember is that no matter how our ancestors came to these shores, that is simply the way it was.  That is self-affirmation.

Like many other readers, I take issue with some of the statements and conclusions the writer has made, but that does not diminish the courage it took to write the article and for the NYTimes to publish it.  As difficult as it may be, if we could all put aside the guilt (whites) and blame (blacks) for just long enough to have meaning dialog and learn from each other.  Isn't it time?

Uh, I'm of European descent and I have always thought Michelle Obama is an impressive, gracious and admirable woman. I don't think any more or less of her just because of this article.

Years ago I was sitting on a crowded train when several people got on and off at a stop. A seat opened up next to the guy I was dating at the time, and without a thought in my head I moved from where I was to sit next to him. Unfortunately for me, my move coincided with a black gentleman sitting next to my old seat. The entire train exploded in accusations of racism against me, as well as others defending me. I was young, and not as self-possessed as I am today, and I sat there in utterly confused and mortified silence until the very next stop... My companion (a very callow young man) was either equally stunned or just character-wise incapable of defending me.....Where I ran off the train close to tears.

I wish that had happened to me as I am today. I have every confidence I could have handled the hecklers graciously, and maybe everyone would have had a better day.

I don't deny that racism is alive and well and utterly hateful. But I don't think we do ourselves any credit when we paint entire populations with a broad brush. Not all Caucasians give a damn about race, and humans overall are so complex that it's dangerous to assume you "just know" their motivations for even simple actions.

Without commenting specifically on Michelle Obama's personal history, I always found it fascinating
how southern whites were able to find convenient loopholes in their strict laws prohibiting interracial mingling.

In general, one would have to assume that the relationship between slave and master is not one of co-equals.

I am still trying to understand the point of this article. The only thing it managed to do was enrage me on a lovely Sunday afternoon. To imply that a slave girl/teenager consented to her own sexual assault is so insulting, it makes my head spin. I could not get past that implication.

We may not be guilty of the sins of our fathers but if any part of the good life we have
comes from the labor of slaves we should not continue to believe that we have done it all ourselves. Mansions in the South and the Withe House were built with the labor of people who were bought and sold like animals and sometimes treated worse.
We should at least remember their work and consider their lives and maybe even thank them for we too were strangers in a strange land.
How do you go about getting tested?

If we--rightly--find it impossible to believe that a contemporary 15-year-old girl could have a consensual relationship with her adult teacher, due to the inability of that student to genuinely consent, then how is it possible to believe that a15-year-old girl could have a consensual relationship with a man who OWNED her? Shame on the Times for perpetuating the romanticization of institutionalized sexual abuse of tens of thousands of African-American women.
@Louise P - I understand.  White is considered to be the norm, so people never say that Laura Bush or Hillary Clinton are prominent white women.

I think you are correct Prof. Sharma that accommodation between the two parties is unlikely. Our hope of achieving balance may necessitate another look at a balanced budget amendment. That might involve, when budget deficits exist, a mandatory cut of 2% per year in future spending coupled with a mandatory and matching $ increase in tax revenue. That mandate would remain in effect each year until the budget was back in balance. Under our current circumstances that would take several years.
Where Congress could not agree, by mid-year, on how and where to effect those spending cuts and tax revenue increases, they automatically would apply across the board to each department that spends and to each form of current tax revenue collection.

In order to keep pace of recovery, however fragile it might be, the imperative of moderate tax-increase with prudent spending cuts to achieve long term deficit control seems crucial,, and the editorial suggestions to that effect appear workable, provided the two warring parties are prepared for some accommodation, which seems unlikely, given the election politics compulsions. Notwithstanding this, the major aspect missing from the editorial advisory list seems no suggestion about defense spending cuts, so essential to restore the budgetary balance.

Yes. They are inevitable, and often produce precisely the adjustment needed to create the conditions for the next period of growth. Unfortunately, nobody likes to admit this, so we persist with the childish fantasy the politicians (of all people!) are wise enough to counteract this natural cycle by timely and sage intervention in free markets. Needless to say, this has never worked in human history but provides employment to tenured academics who consistently fail to accurately predict anything.

I started writing a blog on my hometown (a community within the City of San Diego) because I was appalled by the out-of-date and out-of-touch information travelers were being fed. My head nearly exploded every time I saw visitors walking along the main touristy street slurping up an over-priced ice cream cone when hang gliders, surf lessons, a Tony-Award winning theatre, world-class architecture, fabulous beaches, wildlife, a great farmers' market, free outdoor summertime concerts, and so much more were - literally - within a mile or two. I can't speak to the accuracy of the suicide rates quoted in the article, but I know that a blog written by a local resident provides valuable insider information on places to stay and things to do that just aren't available from other sources.

"Northern Europe’s best-preserved medieval city".

I think the citizens of Tallinn would argue that one.

I have traveled from Chicago to Stockholm a dozen times.  One of the coolest places is the former prison on Långholmen island.  My 12 year old son and I took a room there.  It is this green park like area very close to the central part of the city.
Yes!

@bumsybee

You really miss the point. "Travel writers" make their living shilling for the interests of mass tourism and to provide entertaining and commercial material for their publishers. That's why virtually all the articles in this paper end with hotel, restaurant, and transportation information. This information is provided to facilitate travel.

Otherwise, it's unfortunate but true that almost any place worth spending money and effort to visit is blemished not only by the low hanging fruit of mass tourism but destruction (i.e., Egyptian pharoanic statuary and the site of Angkor Wat), and over the top prices (i.e., Petra in Jordan and the Pacific island of Bora Bora). You need to read between the lines when you bother with this paper's travel section. Or, for that matter, any other. ###

@Kilroy

WHY travel at all. Since you've seen everything, been everywhere, don't you think it's time you followed Lao Tze's advice and tended to your own garden? Yes, that would be good for you. ###
Please consider that the author of this article visited Sweden in April? I bet it would have been a totally different article if he was there in December.
the audience the writer writes for is rather select, no? hence, no harm.
